comments.commentBody:
Iceland's collapse was predicted by the financial journalist Max Keiser in August 2007, who correctly specified the causes, too. Keiser's startlingly prescient report was not seen by many Americans because it was broadcast on Al Jazeera, but it can be viewed on YoutTube at http://tinyurl.com/44jmqq.
Viewers will find Keiser's long interview with none other than Asgeir Jonasson, the shell-shocked bank research director who tells Mr. Halpern that "I was psychologically unable to admit that we were doomed." Keiser's video interview shows him in full-blown denial. After discussing the enormous risks that the bank and its depositors were taking, Keiser asked why the bank continued to add still more risk. Asgeir didn't see the point. Keiser, exasperated, drew the banker's attention to the fearsome Mt. Hekla, Iceland's most dangerous volcano, and asked him whether the fact that it exploded only occasionally would provide enough reassurance to him to approve a mortgage for an expensive vacation home to be built on its slope. Of course not, he replied - no one should build there. The point of the analogy went right by him.

The indebtedness of the next generation is due in part to the heady mixture of pseudo-libertarian ideology, deregulation, and corruption (hitherto rare in Iceland) that is strikingly reminiscent of our own experience. See the report of the Parliament's (Althingi) Special Investigative Commission (http://sic.althingi.is/).

I worked in the Yukon in 2009 at the underworld camp and thought well a million and a half ounces not the mother lode but then the other deposits were discovered. Great story having met some of the people involved. I hope that you continue with regular updates .
He can get 5000 hits, and Damon is still not a HoF outfielder.

When pitchers learn to hold runners on, the stolen base will diminish as a weapon, too.  It's sad that most pitchers lack the skill or the guts to keep runners close.  It seems that they're intimidated by the fans' boos after throwing over once, or holding the ball in the stretch until the hitter bails and is granted time.  You'll see maybe one throw and then, it's off to the races.

IMHO the toughest record in sports to break: Johnny Vandermeer's back-to-back no-hitters. My way of thinking is you would have to throw back-to-back-to-back no-hitters to actually break the record.

As an aside, love the understated compliment "twirler of the first order".
How about the people that work on these farms that use the pesticides.  Who speaks out for them?  Who is fighting for their health? The world we live in.

No disrespect to Sutton, but Tony got a totally different defensive mindset when he became teammates with Kevin Garnett, as all of Garnett's teammates seem to.  Tony's commitment and skill are incredible, and he is a game changing player.  Took him a long time to get there, but he did.

People who are so uptight that they resent other people so much are annoying to me. The guy not walking on the moving belt at the airport might have just had surgery. If someone didn't have bad grammar to whom could we feel superior? And just what is a left lane bandit? And how does he affect your quality of life? Choose your lane and look at the scenery.

I am vapidly irritated by my husband's refusal to put the dishwasher on the heavy cycle when I have categorically told him not to use the normal cycle. The resulting dishes are wet which has to be toweled dry before putting them away and if he happens to do it he puts them away --wet. Boy! it get's me so mad. I guess I am just annoyed at him.

Does petting or massaging your dog count?

http://TheElkaAlmanac.blogspot.com

MOMOTHREE #138- really? you think that was insulting? For having the man's name smeared in the national realm, I was expecting to find words people say after bad days or many drinks. Do Dr.Rhor's  words appear extreme (and, shameful ??) what does he need to be ashamed of? please come back to earth, I dont know where you are, but he is describing at least 6 hospitals that I have seen - and, opposite to Theresa Brown, he is actually blaming the system more than the person (and even that seems offensive to you). Im sure you must be one of those very sacred and rare gentle nurses, who seem predictably  to revert to  a state of shock at seeing such horrid sentiments.... I know, the world is full of shameful cruel people....

I fail to find the insult that Nurse Brown was fuming over. Seems like an obvious jocular respons made by the physiciane to the patient's humerous comment to an oblvious recipient. Either Brown is a clueless concrete thinker or a poor writer; I vote both.

All I know I would not want to work with her and God help those that do. I pity those who now have to work on that unit. As a physician, I will say that each hospital and unit has a unique culture, some quite dysfunctional and others harmonious. Her unit is now surely toxic- you will need a Super-Fund to clean it up. Congrats, nurse Brown.

I have to agree with the readers who questioned Ms. Brown's clinical judgement.  She provided enough clinical information to question why she increased the rate of the medication.  See comment number 34, for example.  I think these questions are relevant to a piece on the stress of clinical management.  It also speaks to the clinical credibility of Ms. Brown, as a Times commentator on medicine.  I agree strongly with the need to preserve patient confidentiality.  In that regard, Ms. Brown writes in a high profile blog that includes pictures of her, has received media attention from the likes of Obama, and has given interviews with her local media. I do worry that there is a high likelihood that patients, patient family members, patient's colleagues, or her own colleagues would recognize themselves or others in her blog posts, many of which describe highly unusual situations.

To me the solution is actually simple. Everyone should act like professional adults. I am also a nurse, and I worked at a hospital where that was the expectation. Anything else was not accepted, whether you were a nurse, physician, CNA, janitor, etc.

Also, if you do witness somebody acting out of line, speak up. If everyone works together to shame the few perpetrators then they won't feel as comfortable acting that way.

One more thing - I do agree that physicians are not any worse than other disciplines. That doesn't excuse abusive behavior, but I think it's unfair to place the majority of the blame on physicians.

I am 64 and live in the U.S.  I am disgusted with every young person assuming that it is alright to address me by my first name without my permission.  Most refuse to address me as "Mrs." when I request it and become offended by  my request.   Also,  I am not senile, stupid or uneducated.  Please do not make this assumption when you look at me and speak to me with the same courtesy you would wish for your own mother or grandmother.  Thanks!

Don't forget the most destructive kind of hoarding -- of money.

It causes mass poverty, which is worse than junk piles in houses, and worse than scabies.

Just Google "green garlic" and you will see a whole page full of photos in its various forms.  Sometimes it looks just like small leeks with  purplish bulbs; sometimes exactly like scallions, or green onions. I guess you have to indentify it by a means other than sight... each photo is very different.
*PLS* Airlines put Parents travelling with small children in ONE section. Nothing worse than having to listen to incessant whining +  endless kicking of the  back of one's seat an entire flight.

Funny I work with medical, nursing and pt students, in a museum.  Yes, we work with these students, to try and hone their skills in observation and listening.  It's amazing to me when I hear them say, "this should be required for ALL medical students!" It's also a bit scary, to hear them also say, "any kind of creativity or compassion is beaten out of us because they're so worried that we get the right answer".  More and more medical schools are incorporating the humanities into education because there is a realization that there's more to being a health care worker than getting the right answer on a test.  So it's about time that this realization came before students get into medical school.  Just hope the MCAT includes some sort of assessment on whether or not a potential candidate has empathy and is an active listener.

I have been aware of 3D printing for the past 9 months, and I am interested in adding a 3rd dimension to my 2D digital artwork.  Does anyone know of a 3d printer available for use (for experimentation or fee for use basis)in the Portland metro area. I find potential of 3D printing for art to be very exciting.

Having been through an early miscarriage then an ectopic pregnancy that nearly killed me and blew a tube at age 35 followed by FIVE failed IVF's I used to get really annoyed when people would say have a glass of wine and 'relax'... Infertility is extremely stressful, frustrating and heartbreaking-- 'relaxing' is the last thing you are thinking about when you are as determined as I was... what I CAN say is.... when out of sheer frustration... I declared it was time to 'take a break' (& focus on my executive-level job) - I then got pregnant at 38 on 'my own' the very next month......yes, my body was super charged with Pergonal -- I was also closely monitored to see what would happen on a 'natural' cycle... even as I was begging for drugs after a folicle was discovered :) - my common sense Swedish-trained doctor said 'no-way'... and like a miracle.... I got pregnant... When I discovered I was pregnant almost 7 weeks later my HCG level was 10,000.... everyone thought the lab had made an error! it was wild- I couldn't believe it myself! I then kept up my travel schedule with work and later had a 9.14 lb. C-section healthy baby girl! I then had another child at 41 with ZERO assistance from my Dr.

Without sounding condescending (because I have been there!) I would like to recommend reading happy books (to calm your brain and disconnect from the stress- focus on other things like I did) and I highly recommend healing yourself as others have also said in 'comments' with a good night's sleep (wear Goodnighties recovery sleepwear - it will help you stay in a deeper stage of REM sleep) .... and that just might be the ticket!

Best of luck to all of you - it's when these over-welcome babies grow into teenagers that one needs to really relax! LOL :)
PEOPLE WHO CRACK THEIR GUM

Dr John says:
"Residents on call, admitting patients from the ER, will ask (like a Passover question), "Why did you choose to come in tonight?"...
Subtext: "Couldn't this have waited until the light of day?"

Um, this question has nothing to do with the 'light of day' and everything to do with the fact that the attending is bound to ask the resident the Exact Same Question when the patient is presented in the morning.

Seems to be of a piece with emotionally fragile, chronically homeless people who might carry 50 pounds of "essentials" in 12 plastic shopping bags while wearing 4 layers of clothing. The difference? They haven't a residence to fill up.

~ William McCloskey, Pittsburgh
